Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports theoretical research on dipolar Fermi gases. In such ultracold gases of molecules, interactions between the electric dipole moments of the molecules lead to a rich array of unusual quantum phases. They belong to the latest breeds of quantum matter engineered in laboratories by precise control of molecules using laser light. The system has the potential to simulate and solve some profound mysteries regarding strongly interacting fermions with long-range interactions. The research will chart out the phase diagrams of dipolar fermions on two-dimensional optical lattices. The goal is to discover and understand novel phases of matter and predict their experimental signatures. The results can provide input for current and future experiments. The knowledge acquired will contribute to the understanding of interacting fermions in general, a subject of fundamental importance to physics and material science. Better understanding and consequently better control over the system will help to achieve other goals of ultracold molecule research, such as precision measurement and quantum computation.

The award will stimulate deeper dialogue between many body physics and Atomic, Molecular, and Optical physics at the interdisciplinary frontier of ultracold molecules. It will also strengthen the collaboration between George Mason University and the National Institute of Standards and Technology on cold atoms research. The principal investigator will continue to coach local high school students on independent research projects to compete in the Intel and Siemens Science and Engineering Fair.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on the collective properties of "tiny bar magnets", dilute gases of atoms and molecules that carry electrical or magnetic dipole moments and interact strongly with each other. Such degenerate dipolar quantum gases made their debut recently in experiments. At low temperatures, they form intricate quantum phases, i.e., ordering patterns dictated by quantum mechanical laws, which remain largely unexplored or poorly understood. While appearing exotic, these systems promise to become a powerful quantum simulator for interacting fermions with tunable, long-range interactions. One of the advantages of quantum simulators based on dipolar molecules is the ability to go beyond the short-range contact interaction in alkali atoms, and therefore shed more light on correlated electronic materials where Coulomb interactions dominate.


Despite the rapid theoretical developments in recent years, it remains a significant challenge to reliably predict the phase diagrams of interacting dipolar Fermi gases. Ongoing experiments demand theoretical input, e.g., what parameter regimes to look for interesting many-body phases. This project identifies the main difficulty of the theoretical problem -- competing orders, or more precisely competing many-body instabilities. A new approach based on functional renormalization group is employed to treat, for the first time, all relevant instabilities on equal footing without bias. The main research outcomes include the zero temperature phase diagram of dipolar Fermi gases on square lattice for spinless and spin 1/2 case, and the finite temperature phase diagram of dipolar Fermi gas in continuum. New phases of matter, such as Bond Order Solid, p-wave spin density wave, and an unexpected CDW1 phases were discovered. The research results have been reported in peer reviewed journals such as Physical Review Letters and Physical Review A.  

The project supported the development of numerical algorithms and computer codes to study interacting Fermi gases. It trained students and postdocs in many-body physics and high performance computing. It also enhanced collaborations with physicists at National Institute of Standards and Technology.
